Issues.Title: Fix handle creation on DateTimePicker.Enabled change
Issues.Body:
This PR fixes an incorrect code in PR #4374. 

This code is using GetWindowLong and SetWindowLong on OnEnabledChanged. This could cause a handle creation before the control is displayed.

See discussion here : https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4374#discussion_r621914769

This issue appears to be similar to https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4610, with the root cause introduced in https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/4525.

**Expected behavior:**

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4403806/116522233-4bbe3d00-a918-11eb-8ef9-ddd935e6954d.png)

With this change it appears to work:

```diff
diff --git a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
index 123873bc7..f30edc3b5 100644
--- a/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
+++ b/src/System.Windows.Forms/src/System/Windows/Forms/LinkLabel.cs
@@ -1506,7 +1506,7 @@ namespace System.Windows.Forms
                             font,
                             clientRectWithPadding,
                             brushColor,
-                            CreateTextFormatFlags(clientRectWithPadding.Size));
+                            CreateTextFormatFlags(clientRectWithPadding.Size) | TextFormatFlags.PreserveGraphicsClipping | TextFormatFlags.PreserveGraphicsTranslateTransform);
                     }
 
                     if (Focused && ShowFocusCues && FocusLink == link)
```

Issues.Title: Disabling a focused TextBox draws TextBox wrong
Issues.Body:
**.NET Core Version:**

SDK: 5.0.202 (db7cc87d51)
Runtime: 5.0.5 (2f740adc14)

**Problem description:**

If a focused textbox is disabled while having the focus, it does not display correctly:

Here are 2 textboxes where the top one has focus:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/116527782-573f4300-a8db-11eb-9d28-ae798ec93b96.png)

The top one is now disabled, notice the weird looking border, it should look like the bottom one:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80055480/116527560-17785b80-a8db-11eb-866c-2c332ff02235.png)


**Repro:**

I have attached a sample project showing the problem. There are 2 textboxes and a button. The button disables both textboxes. The textbox with the focus shows the problem:
[TestDisableTextBox.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6397707/TestDisableTextBox.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disabling a focused TextBox draws TextBox wrong" (#4856)

Issues.Title: WinForms HighDPI PerMonitorV2 windows launched on secondary monitor is incorrectly scaled
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

**.NET Core Version:**

SDK: 5.0.202 (db7cc87d51)
Runtime: 5.0.5 (2f740adc14)


**Problem description:**

If the main application window is not launched on the main monitor it scales wrong, because Form.DeviceDpi has the DPI-Settings of the main monitor.

**Minimal repro:**
- Create new .NET-Core 5.0 WinForms app
- Set Application.SetHighDpiMode(HighDpiMode.PerMonitorV2)
- Open the forms designer for Form1
- Set AutoScaleMode = Dpi
- Set StartPosition = CenterScreen;

-> Build and run the project by launching it not on your primary monitor, but on a secondary monitor with different DPI from the primary monitor. You can do this for example by launching debugging from Visual Studio and quickly focusing a window on another monitor so that this monitor gets the focus.

I have attached a sample project with the repro steps described above here:
[TestDpiChanging.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6396835/TestDpiChanging.zip)

Issues.Title: Adding logic for announcing of column header by Narrator
Issues.Body:
Fixes #3745


## Proposed changes
- Added "AnnounceColumnHeader" method for announcing the column header. When the user hovers over the ColumnHeader, we receive an event for redrawing. Using this event, we get data about the columns header and the shift of coordinates due to scrolling. Using the calculated coordinates, we make a HITTEST API request. From this request, we get data about the column index and announce header using the this index.

Issues.Title: [Accessibility] The Inspect tree displays information doesn't refresh timely when moving a listViewItem from default listViewGroup to another listViewGroup
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 
.NET SDK 6.0.100-preview.5.21226.11

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
Yes

**More info:**
1. This is a not regression issue, it also reproduced on .NET framework 4.8, .NET core 3.1 & .NET 5.0.
2. The issue is related to the fact that the Inspect tree displays information that is relevant at the time the data is received. To update the data again, the user should collapse and re-expand the item. **This is a general problem for the Inspect, not specifically related to the ListView.**

**Minimal repro:** 
[TestApp_Core.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6383007/TestApp_Core.zip)

1. Create an app with ListView which added several ListViewItems
2. Add "Test" ListViewGroup to the ListView
3. Add an event so that when you click on a special button, the second ListViewItem is moved to the "Test" ListViewGroup.
4. Run the app
5. Run the Inspect
6. Select the item2 in inspect tree
7. Press the Replace button, at this time, the item2 is moved to the "Test" group
8. Focus on item2 using mouse
9. Observe the structure of listView in inspect tree

**Actual behavior:**
The item2 is displayed in both "default" ListViewGroup and "Test" ListViewGroup.
After click refresh button in inspect, the item2 in "default" ListViewGroup disappeared.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/62929087/116208319-63a88c00-a773-11eb-900a-c2a641e4a005.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The item2 should only display in "Test" ListViewGroup.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Accessibility] The Inspect tree displays information doesn't refresh timely when moving a listViewItem from default listViewGroup to another listViewGroup" (#4851)

Issues.Title: Optimization of methods and properties of ListView accessibility objects
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes
In order to simplify and optimize the operation of `ListView` accessibility objects, the following changes have been made:
- An internal `GetChildIndex` method has been added. It is necessary so that all the conditions of getting the index are in the parent (`ListView` and `ListViewGroup`). In this case, the `ListViewItem` or `ListViewGroup` will not have to know who their parent is and what view the `ListView` is currently in. They just ask the parent for the index and work with it.
- The logic for getting the index of the `ListViewItem` has been optimized. Previously, we called the `GetChildCount` method to get the number of children, and then using the index and the `GetChild` method, we got the child to check. The disadvantage of this approach is that the `GetChild` method, when checking the index, again called the `GetChildCount` method. That is, to find the twentieth element, we called the `GetChildCount` method 21 times. Considering that each time the `GetChildCount` method is called, the list of visible `ListViewGroups` and visible `ListViewItems` is generated anew, this algorithm is very inefficient. Now we get a list of objects once and go through it, in search of the required object
- Added a new `GroupsDisplayed` property to find out if `ListViewGroups` are currently displayed or not. This is necessary to optimize performance and avoid duplication of the same logic across all `ListView` accessibility objects.
- Improved the `GetVisibleGroups` method. Now, when generating the list of visible `ListViewGroups`, it takes into account the presence or absence of a default `ListViewGroup`. This helps to avoid additional checks in `GetChild` and `GetChildCount` methods.
- As a result of the changes above, the work of the `GetChild` and `GetChildCount` method was optimized and simplified.
- The logic of the `Bounds` property and `FragmentNavigate`, `GetChild`, `GetChildIndex` and `SetFocus` methods has been changed. Previously, when working with these properties and methods, we took into account only the `Virtual mode` property. However, in addition to it, there are `ShowGroups`, `View`, `Groups` and `Application.UseVisualStyles` properties that also affect the work of `ListViewGroups`. Now all these properties are taken into account when working with `ListViewGroups`.
- In order to optimize the work of `ListViewItemAccessibleObjects`, the logic for working with `ListViewGroups` was borrowed from the #4841.
- Updated unit tests
<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact
- No
## Regression? 
- No

## Risk
- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- Unit tests

- Microsoft Windows Version 10.0.19041.388
- .NET Core SDK: 6.0.100-preview.2.21155.3

Issues.Title: Add MetadataUpdateHandler to WinForms to repaint all open forms
Issues.Body:
## Proposed changes

.NET hot reload enables changes to be made to an app while it's running.  If you were to patch a control's OnPaint routine, for example, the next time that was invoked, it would end up running the newly patched code.  However, nothing at the runtime level applying updates automatically triggers Windows Forms to refresh its controls.  Instead, a notification mechanism is used to invoke any interested listeners about an update.  Windows Forms can have its own listener, which it can use to do anything it would like in response to the update notification.  This PR adds such a listener, and uses it to refresh every open form in the application.  Future updates to it could be used to do other things, like request that data bound controls rebind, in case the thing they're bound to has changed in some way. (Note that TypeDescriptor.Refresh is invoked via the same mechanism, so any control's listening to TypeDescriptor.Refreshed will automatically be notified as well; this appears to only be the case for PropertyGrid today.)

## Customer Impact

Windows Forms apps being used with hot reload automatically refresh in response to a hot reload update.

## Regression? 

No

## Risk

The hot reload work is still in flight and the pattern employed by this loosely-coupled mechanism is still in development; the pattern may evolve, in which case we'll need to update it along with all the other handlers we've added / are adding in .NET 6.

## Test methodology

Build the changes locally and patched my installed nightly .NET 6 build.  Then use hot reload with several apps, including some that had custom OnPaint overrides, which I could change to see that hot reload edits forced a repaint.

cc: @KlausLoeffelmann, @JeremyKuhne, @pranavkm, @tommcdon, @mikem8361, @LyalinDotCom

Issues.Title: [HDPI] CheckBox doesn't respect system font scaling
Issues.Body:
* .NET Core Version: all up to latest (5.0.5)

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: No because .NET Framework doesn't respect system font scaling at all.

**Problem description:**
Probably all CheckBox  stuff (`CheckBox`, `TreeView` with checkboxes, `CheckBoxRenderer` e.t.c.) doesn't respect system font scaling for check box image:
![Snipaste_2021-04-25_17-33-44](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17767561/115997795-1dc1bb80-a5ed-11eb-9ef8-c478ac0ecb7d.png)
P.s. TreeView plus/minus signs also not increasing.

**Expected behavior:**
I think image must scale with Font too (especially because of font scaling is used by default). It's just pointless to enlarge the text, but not enlarge the checkbox image. But if it's by design, feel free to close this issue.

**Minimal repro:**
Any WinForm app with `HighDpiMode.SystemAware` + `CheckBox` and increased System font.

Issues.Title: ListViewItemAccessibleObject doesn't respect updating a group
Issues.Body:
Fixes #4839


## Proposed changes
- The issue is reproduced because during the creation of the ListViewItemAccessibilityObject, we save the current value of the ListViewGroup and it is no longer updated. This is not the right approach because the user can change the ListViewGroup of a ListViewItem or remove ListViewGroups from the ListView. Currently we use the "OwningGroup" property, which, on each call, calculates whether the ListView has ListViewGroups and which ListViewGroup the ListViewItem is in.

- Also, an issue with an attempt to get "Bounds" property when the Handle is not created has been fixed. Now, in the absence of a Handle, we immediately return an empty rectangle

- Added and updated unit tests 

<!-- We are in TELL-MODE the following section must be completed -->

## Customer Impact
Before fix:
![Issue-4839-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/115868973-e82e9e00-a445-11eb-83ac-5a9a35bae963.png)

After fix:
![Issue-4839-after](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/115869001-ef55ac00-a445-11eb-86fd-40efcaa03e05.png)

## Regression? 

- Yes (from #3223)

## Risk
- Minimal

## Test methodology <!-- How did you ensure quality? -->
- CTI team
- Unit tests

## Accessibility testing  <!-- Remove this section if PR does not change UI -->
- Inspector
 
## Test environment(s) <!-- Remove any that don't apply -->
- Microsoft Windows Version 10.0.19041.388
- .NET Core SDK: 6.0.100-preview.2.21155.3

Issues.Title: ListViewItemAccessibleObject does not update data about ListViewGroup when moved to another ListViewGroup
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

.NET Core Version: 
- 6.0.100-preview.2.21155.3

Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: 
- No. It is regression from #3223

**Minimal repro:**
1. Create an app with `ListView`
2. Add several `ListViewItems` to a `ListView`
3. Add "Test" `ListViewGroup` to the `ListView`
4. Add an event so that when you click on a special button, the second `ListViewItem` is moved to the "Test" `ListViewGroup`.
5. Run the application
6. Run Inspect
7. Get data about the second `ListViewItem` through the Inspect
8. Press a special button (the second 'ListViewItem' is moved to the "Test" `ListViewGroup`)

**Actual behavior:**
The `ListViewItem` is still displayed in the default `ListViewGroup` in the Inspect tree. The `ListViewItem` displays the default `ListViewGroup` as a parent.
![Issue-4839-before](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23376742/115856625-659de280-a435-11eb-9214-bcc938576d13.png)

**Expected behavior:**
The `ListViewItem` should be displayed in the "Test" `ListViewGroup` in the Inspect tree. The `ListViewItem` should display the "Test" `ListViewGroup` as a parent
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ListViewItemAccessibleObject does not update data about ListViewGroup when moved to another ListViewGroup" (#4839)

Issues.Title: Winforms-When added the option(button) in panel not shown the option with HighDpi and custom scaling applied in .NET 5.0
Issues.Body: When setting the scaling 100% Control size and alignment are proper in the panel with HighDpi in the .Net 5.0 application. Please refer to the below screenshot for your reference, **DPI enabled:** ![Dpi100Scaling](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58214164/115852229-78b8ae80-a445-11eb-84cb-3c227f5b9c53.png) **Scaling:** ![Scaling](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58214164/115852066-4b6c0080-a445-11eb-9ccd-e4e03c65fa8c.png) **Control size and alignment are proper in the panel with HighDpi 100% scaling** ![Buttonalignedanddisplayproperly](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58214164/115852363-a00f7b80-a445-11eb-935a-e36f5ebac483.png) When setting the custom scaling 150% Control size and alignment is not proper in the panel with HighDpi in the .Net 5.0 application. Please refer to the below screenshot for your reference, **DPI enabled:** **Scaling:** **Control size and alignment are not proper in the panel with HighDpi 150% scaling** Steps to reproduce the bug: 1.Run the Sample. 2.Click the button in the form. **Sample:** [Sample.zip](https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/files/6364359/Sample.zip) **Expected Behavior:** The button should be properly aligned and display the text while setting custom scaling (150%). **Observed Behavior:** The button is not properly added and aligned. Button text is not shown while setting custom scaling (150%). Can anyone share an idea to resolve the reported problem? Regards, Vijayarasan S
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Winforms-When added the option(button) in panel not shown the option with HighDpi and custom scaling applied in .NET 5.0" (#4838)

Issues.Title: ToolStripControlHost with a custom control freezes UIA clients
Issues.Body:
<!-- Read https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/blob/main/docs/issue-guide.md -->

* .NET Core Version: 6.0

* Have you experienced this same bug with .NET Framework?: Yes

* Original bug: [1313197](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1313197?src=WorkItemMention&src-action=artifact_link)

**Problem description:**
- If a ToolStrip has ToolStripControlHost item, Inspect can't show its accessbiility tree and freezes:
![hMfSttv4cb](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/115824301-64a68a00-a410-11eb-8666-6beb0b5c4a04.gif)


**Expected behavior:**
- Inspect shows a correct accessbiility tree for a ToolStrip with a ToolStripControlHost:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/49272759/115823495-13e26180-a40f-11eb-92f9-3e9c485cbdce.png)


**Minimal repro:**
- Create a .NET 6.0 app
- Add a ToolStrip to the app
- Create ToolStripControlHost with some control (eg. `new ToolStripControlHost(new RadioButton())`) and add it to the ToolStrip items
- Add several any items to ToolStrip (optional)
- Run the app and check the accessibility tree using Inspect
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ToolStripControlHost with a custom control freezes UIA clients" (#4835)
